subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Anti-patterns
msgSnippet: ... It s /no/ way to test for exceptions. How would I write an assertion? :) (I imagine that was your point.) ... ...unless you want to check the exception
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> The point was that letting the method throw and declare the exception in the
> throws clause is not considered the best way to test for exceptions.

It's /no/ way to test for exceptions. How would I write an assertion? :)
(I imagine that was your point.)

> Of course, all of this is moot with JUnit4 / TestNG :-)
...unless you want to check the exception /object/ and not just its
type. The best I've seen for that so far is the block idiom:

assertThrows(closure, expectedException);

where closure is

new ExceptionalClosure() {
public void execute() throws Exception {
// code that might throw an exception here
}
}

and assertThrows does what you'd expect:

public void assertThrows(ExceptionalClosure closure, Exception expected) {
try {
closure.execute();
fail("Closure should have thrown an exception, but didn't.");
}
catch (Exception caught) {
assertEquals("Caught different exception", expected, caught);
}
}

Conceptually, it's simpler, but syntax-wise, it sucks. In a language
that treats code blocks with respect, it'd be better.
